location: The Grecian camp. Before Achilles tent.

lines.text: Enter ACHILLES and PATROCLUS

lines.speaker: achilles
lines.text: Ill heat his blood with Greekish wine tonight, Which with my scimitar Ill cool tomorrow. Patroclus, let us feast him to the height.

lines.speaker: patroclus
lines.text: Here comes Thersites.
Enter THERSITES

lines.speaker: achilles
lines.text: How now, thou core of envy! Thou crusty batch of nature, whats the news

lines.speaker: thersites
lines.text: Why, thou picture of what thou seemest, and idol of idiot worshippers, heres a letter for thee.

lines.speaker: achilles
lines.text: From whence, fragment

lines.speaker: thersites
lines.text: Why, thou full dish of fool, from Troy.

lines.speaker: patroclus
lines.text: Who keeps the tent now

lines.speaker: thersites
lines.text: The surgeons box, or the patients wound.

lines.speaker: patroclus
lines.text: Well said, adversity! and what need these tricks

lines.speaker: thersites
lines.text: Prithee, be silent, boy I profit not by thy talk: thou art thought to be Achilles male varlet.

lines.speaker: patroclus
lines.text: Male varlet, you rogue! whats that

lines.speaker: thersites
lines.text: Why, his masculine whore. Now, the rotten diseases of the south, the gutsgriping, ruptures, catarrhs, loads o gravel i the back, lethargies, cold palsies, raw eyes, dirtrotten livers, wheezing lungs, bladders full of imposthume, sciaticas, limekilns i the palm, incurable boneache, and the rivelled feesimple of the tetter, take and take again such preposterous discoveries!

lines.speaker: patroclus
lines.text: Why thou damnable box of envy, thou, what meanest thou to curse thus

lines.speaker: thersites
lines.text: Do I curse thee

lines.speaker: patroclus
lines.text: Why no, you ruinous butt, you whoreson indistinguishable cur, no.

lines.speaker: thersites
lines.text: No! why art thou then exasperate, thou idle immaterial skein of sleavesilk, thou green sarcenet flap for a sore eye, thou tassel of a prodigals purse, thou Ah, how the poor world is pestered with such waterflies, diminutives of nature!

lines.speaker: patroclus
lines.text: Out, gall!

lines.speaker: thersites
lines.text: Finchegg!

lines.speaker: achilles
lines.text: My sweet Patroclus, I am thwarted quite From my great purpose in tomorrows battle. Here is a letter from Queen Hecuba, A token from her daughter, my fair love, Both taxing me and gaging me to keep An oath that I have sworn. I will not break it: Fall Greeks fail fame honour or go or stay My major vow lies here, this Ill obey. Come, come, Thersites, help to trim my tent: This night in banqueting must all be spent. Away, Patroclus!
Exeunt ACHILLES and PATROCLUS

lines.speaker: thersites
lines.text: With too much blood and too little brain, these two may run mad but, if with too much brain and too little blood they do, Ill be a curer of madmen. Heres Agamemnon, an honest fellow enough and one that loves quails but he has not so much brain as earwax: and the goodly transformation of Jupiter there, his brother, the bull,the primitive statue, and oblique memorial of cuckolds a thrifty shoeinghorn in a chain, hanging at his brothers leg,to what form but that he is, should wit larded with malice and malice forced with wit turn him to To an ass, were nothing he is both ass and ox: to an ox, were nothing he is both ox and ass. To be a dog, a mule, a cat, a fitchew, a toad, a lizard, an owl, a puttock, or a herring without a roe, I would not care but to be Menelaus, I would conspire against destiny. Ask me not, what I would be, if I were not Thersites for I care not to be the louse of a lazar, so I were not Menelaus! Heyday! spirits and fires!
Enter HECTOR, TROILUS, AJAX, AGAMEMNON, ULYSSES, NESTOR, MENELAUS, and DIOMEDES, with lights

lines.speaker: agamemnon
lines.text: We go wrong, we go wrong.

lines.speaker: ajax
lines.text: No, yonder tis There, where we see the lights.

lines.speaker: hector
lines.text: I trouble you.

lines.speaker: ajax
lines.text: No, not a whit.

lines.speaker: ulysses
lines.text: Here comes himself to guide you.
Reenter ACHILLES

lines.speaker: achilles
lines.text: Welcome, brave Hector welcome, princes all.

lines.speaker: agamemnon
lines.text: So now, fair prince of Troy, I bid good night. Ajax commands the guard to tend on you.

lines.speaker: hector
lines.text: Thanks and good night to the Greeks general.

lines.speaker: menelaus
lines.text: Good night, my lord.

lines.speaker: hector
lines.text: Good night, sweet lord Menelaus.

lines.speaker: thersites
lines.text: Sweet draught: sweet quoth a! sweet sink, sweet sewer.

lines.speaker: achilles
lines.text: Good night and welcome, both at once, to those That go or tarry.

lines.speaker: agamemnon
lines.text: Good night.
Exeunt AGAMEMNON and MENELAUS

lines.speaker: achilles
lines.text: Old Nestor tarries and you too, Diomed, Keep Hector company an hour or two.

lines.speaker: diomedes
lines.text: I cannot, lord I have important business, The tide whereof is now. Good night, great Hector.

lines.speaker: hector
lines.text: Give me your hand.

lines.speaker: ulysses
lines.text: [Aside to TROILUS]  Follow his torch he goes to Calchas tent: Ill keep you company.

lines.speaker: troilus
lines.text: Sweet sir, you honour me.

lines.speaker: hector
lines.text: And so, good night. Exit DIOMEDES ULYSSES and TROILUS following

lines.speaker: achilles
lines.text: Come, come, enter my tent.
Exeunt ACHILLES, HECTOR, AJAX, and NESTOR

lines.speaker: thersites
lines.text: That same Diomeds a falsehearted rogue, a most unjust knave I will no more trust him when he leers than I will a serpent when he hisses: he will spend his mouth, and promise, like Brabbler the hound: but when he performs, astronomers foretell it it is prodigious, there will come some change the sun borrows of the moon, when Diomed keeps his word. I will rather leave to see Hector, than not to dog him: they say he keeps a Trojan drab, and uses the traitor Calchas tent: Ill after. Nothing but lechery! all incontinent varlets!
Exit
